whatIs.title: What Is a Promissory Note?
content: A Promissory Note is a written, signed promise by one party (the “Borrower” or “Maker”) to pay a specific sum of money to another party (the “Lender” or “Holder”) on a certain date or on demand.
It typically outlines the loan amount (principal), interest rate (if any), repayment schedule, and what happens if the Borrower defaults.
Think of it as a formal IOU that's legally enforceable.

rows: Personal loan to family/friends
Prevents misunderstandings, preserves relationships, tax proof if interest is charged.
Business owner lending to their LLC/Corp
Maintains corporate veil, clean bookkeeping, proves legitimate loan vs. capital contribution.
Seller-financed real estate deals (seller carryback)
Evidence of debt for title insurers, tax authorities; allows foreclosure if unpaid.
Equipment or vehicle sold on installments
Allows seller to reclaim asset on default if note is secured.
Large payday advances to employees
Satisfies payroll auditors, documents repayment terms clearly.

varieties.title: Promissory Note Varieties
items: Simple (Unsecured): No collateral pledged; relies on Borrower’s creditworthiness.
Secured: Identifies specific collateral (e.g., car, equipment, real estate) the Lender can seize if unpaid. Often requires a separate Security Agreement.
Demand: Payable any time the Lender “calls” the balance due, with or without specified notice.
Installment (Amortized): Regular payments of principal and interest over a set term.
Installment with Balloon: Smaller periodic payments (often interest-only) with a large lump-sum principal payment at the end.
Interest-Only: Borrower pays only interest during the loan term; principal is repaid in full at maturity.
Master Note / Line of Credit: Allows for a revolving balance up to a maximum credit limit, with draws and repayments over time.

rows: Full Legal Names & Addresses (Borrower & Lender)
Ensures correct parties are bound; necessary for enforcement.
Principal Amount
Clearly states the exact amount loaned, avoiding disputes.
Interest Rate & Calculation Method
Specifies APR, compounding (if any), and checks for usury law compliance.
Repayment Schedule
Dates, frequency (monthly, quarterly), payment amounts, or lump sum maturity date.
Late-Fee Formula
Defines penalties for missed payments (e.g., flat fee or percentage after grace period).
Prepayment Policy
States whether early payoff is allowed and if any penalty applies.
Default & Remedies
Outlines what constitutes a default (e.g., missed payment) and Lender’s rights (e.g., acceleration clause, collection costs).
Collateral Description (for Secured Notes)
Precise identification of assets securing the loan (VIN, serial numbers, legal property description).
Governing Law & Venue
Specifies which state’s laws apply and where legal action can be taken.
Signatures (Borrower, Lender, Witnesses/Notary if required)
Makes the contract legally binding. Notarization adds authenticity and may be required in some states for certain notes.

stateRules.title: State-Specific Rules & Usury Caps
stateRules.content: Interest-rate ceilings (usury laws) vary significantly by state and loan type (e.g., personal vs. business). For example, New York's general civil usury cap is 16%, while Texas allows up to 18% for most consumer loans but has higher limits for certain contract types. Our template:
items: Flags interest rates that likely exceed your state’s civil usury limit based on standard loan types.
Alerts you if notarization is commonly required or recommended in your state for promissory notes.
Provides links to state-specific resources for deeper research if needed.
stateRules.disclaimer: Always verify with local statutes or a legal professional, as usury laws can be complex.

checklist.title: Lender & Borrower Checklist
items: Verify Legal Names & IDs: Ensure names match government-issued identification.
Confirm Loan Terms: Both parties understand and agree on principal, interest, and repayment.
Collateral Documentation (if secured): Attach photos, serial numbers, or property deeds for reference.
File UCC-1 (for secured business loans): Perfects lender's security interest in business collateral.
Keep Payment Records: Both parties should maintain a ledger of payments made and received.
Provide IRS Form 1099-INT (if applicable): Lender reports interest income paid by borrower if over $600/year in some cases.

q1.question: Is an e-signed promissory note legally binding?
q1.answer: Yes. Under the U.S. Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce (E-SIGN) Act and the Uniform Electronic Transactions Act (UETA) adopted by most states, electronic signatures carry the same legal weight as handwritten signatures for most transactions, including promissory notes.

q2.question: Do I need a witness or notary for a promissory note?
q2.answer: Requirements vary by state and the nature of the loan. While not always mandatory for simple notes, notarization or witness signatures can significantly strengthen the note's enforceability by verifying the identities of the signers. Some states require it for notes involving real estate or larger sums. Our platform will indicate if notarization is recommended for your state.

q3.question: What happens if the borrower defaults on the promissory note?
q3.answer: If a borrower defaults (e.g., misses payments), the lender can take legal action as outlined in the note's 'Default & Remedies' clause. This may include demanding full repayment of the outstanding balance (acceleration), suing for the debt, or, if the note is secured, seizing the specified collateral. Collection costs and attorney fees may also be recoverable if stipulated.

q4.question: Can I change the terms of a promissory note later?
q4.answer: Yes, the terms of a promissory note can be changed if both the lender and borrower agree in writing. This is typically done through a 'Promissory Note Amendment' or 'Modification Agreement,' which should be signed by all parties. 123LegalDoc offers templates for such amendments.

q5.question: Is interest earned from a promissory note taxable?
q5.answer: Yes, interest income received by the lender is generally taxable and must be reported to the IRS. The borrower may be able to deduct interest paid if the loan was for business, investment, or certain educational purposes, subject to IRS rules.
